metadata.title:
Repeated avian infectious bronchitis virus infections within a single chicken
farm

body_text.text:
The authors declare that there are no conflicts of interest associated with this paper. No animal experiments were conducted in
this study, except obtaining the IBV infected chickens organs from the farm. The animal
ethics committee was not involved in this study.
body_text.section: CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT AND OTHERS

FIGREF0.text:
Fig. 1.: Partial sequence of the S gene of IBV. Samples isolated from tracheas
and kidneys of six chickens were amplified by RT-PCR either with the S1 primer pair (A)
or S2 primer pair (B). DNA fragments read from both termini by the
dideoxy-chain-termination method were aligned. Asterisks show the nucleotides that are
identical among the samples. Blanks show the nucleotides that differ between tracheas
and kidneys. The 653 bp-regions of S1 (A) and the 379 bp-regions of S2 (B) are shown. A:
Open circles indicated on the nucleotides shows the minor nucleotide changes found in
one of six chickens (A63G, T86C and C246T). B: Numbers (1–36) shown on the nucleotides
in the blank space corresponds to those in Fig.
2.

FIGREF1.text:
Fig. 2.: Minor peaks in the S2 region of trachea samples. Representative nucleotide sequencing
peaks of the S2 region of trachea samples are shown. Green, black, blue, and red lines
show the four nucleotide bases, adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine, respectively.
Thirty-six nucleotides that differed between the samples obtained from tracheas and
kidneys are marked and boxed. Under the main nucleotide peak, a smaller peak is present,
but its color is identical to that in the kidney sample.

FIGREF2.text:
Fig. 3.: Phylogenetic tree based on the partial S gene sequences. Phylogenetic
tree analysis based on the nucleotide sequences of amplified S1 (A) and S2 (B) regions
were performed using the unweighted pair group method with arithmetic mean (UPGMA)
method. Naming of groups followed previous publications [9,10,11,12,13]. Sequences of representative IBV were either downloaded through NCBI,
PubMed, Nucleotide-searching site, or obtained by our own sequencing.
